This makes me think of ancient civilizations.  Due to their limited resources, they couldn't travel far in any direction, so they just assumed that the world is just that, a vast flat land and an impossible-to-reach heaven.  It's only in pretty recent years (in terms of human and world history) that we notice the existence of "space" and "the universe".  By applying the same logic, we may have the privilege to learn about the existence of the world outside of Earth, but we're still trapped here, our knowledge is limited to what we can observe, which isn't a lot, and our exploration can only go so far, and we may never be able to even leave the Milky Way or even our Solar System due to our limited resources and technology.  When you think about it, humanity has gone a long way, but we aren't that far away from our ancestors.

I personally don't study astronomy or cosmology, just an enthusiast, so don't quote me on anything I say here!

I normally find Kurzgesagt videos quite true with my retained information, but in this video where it says that the planets cool to -270 Celsius, I believe this to be untrue, -273 is absolute zero, meaning the absolute non-presence of heat. In this universe, where there is not many insulating barriers, this would be untrue. As humans, we barely have the technology to make an absolute zero environment, and we could only do it for a couple seconds. From what I've seen, the rogue planet would absorb the remaining heat from stars and red dwarfs from thousands of light-years away, to the point where from what I understand, should stay between -170 and -230.

As I said, don't quote me on any of this.

Honestly, in a scenario like that, where intelligent life wouldn't be able to produce fire and forge metals, the most deadly weapon they could have would be the ice itself.

Not only will be the most abundant material available as will have one lethal property: it steals heat from it surroundings while it melts. Imagine living in a dark world where there's hardly enough heat to sustain life and suddenly be stroke by an spear made of ice with an pointy stone edge, due to some war for the control of the hottest areas in volcanic activity regions, and now you're wounded and losing crucial body heat.

Of course, extracting and shaping the ice above it's hard and risky, but the war effort is known to have great effects on the technological development. As long the wars continues, one day, a violent war-based civilization could break thought the ice, and a warrior species may or may not realize that life is more than freezing water, ice and killing.

OK, so I just had a weird but happy thought. What if one of these intelligent life bearing rogue planets by some miracle coincidence managed to not only get captured by a new star but also got captured into the Goldilocks zone for that planet’s atmosphere composition. In that case, the closed system now has a new comparably massive energy input. This results in the bedrock ice melting and now that intelligent life has more energy than it knows really what to do with what happens to that civilization. Because keep in mind there is still no wood or fossil fuels there is still no real way to refine metals but at least now they can look at the pretty stars in the Sky and have a day-night cycle provided they are not tidally locked. All in all, they would probably be very confused.

What's the likelihood of a rogue planet returning into the orbit of another star? I could imagine some (probably insanely unlikely scenario) where, during the life of a planet like Earth, life begins to develop as it revolves around the Sun, meaning their life forms are very similar to ours. Then another star comes along and rips it out of orbit, killing everything that doesn't dwell on the ocean floor. The surviving organisms live on the ocean floor for millions and millions of years, but then the planet just so happens to be pulled into the orbit of another star it is passing by. Then the ice melts, and the life forms from the ocean are able to evolve to inhabit the surface once again. I'm guessing the chances of such a thing happening for a single planet though are probably pretty close to zero.

I think you're overlooking a few points.
You say water is vital to the development of life, but really what you're saying is that a liquid that will allow other elements to mix and bond to each other. On an alien planet that liquid could be something other than water. This could mean life develops from something other than a carbon base like we did.

When you say underwater life forms would not have fire to forge a civilization, I think hydrothermal vents. Those vents are more than hot enough to cook food or forge metal.

I think it's wrong to assume life has to develop the way life on earth did. And assuming life out there developed like life down here could mean we never "see" the life out there. We need to open our minds to other possibilities.

Lars Von Trier made a movie called “Melancholia”. It’s about the devastating, all consuming toll of severe depression. Also, it just so happens that a rogue planet named Melancholia is on course for earth. The film perfectly portrays the dynamic between clinically depressed people, who typically handle the worst possible news better than those who’re mentally healthy. Depressed people always expect the worst, which contributes to their overall calmness when the worst actually happens. It won several awards, including best film at the Cannes film festival and is widely considered to be one of the best films of the past 20 years. It’s arthouse and not for everyone, but give it a shot. I won’t spoil the ending for you. 🤭

The part about planet's internal heat is not entirely correct. It suggests that the core's energy comes only from primordial heat (retained from early impacts and planet formation stage) slowly cooling down. In fact even in the case of Earth scientists estimate that radioactive decay is the biggest contributor to heat content and primordial heat is second. It is also entirely possible that in different solar systems planets with more radioactive cores form producing even more energy this way. This would mostly depend on the type of star that was there before it went supernova (pretty much all solid planets came from at least second generation of stars, because at first there was only Hydrogen, Helium and minute amounts of Lithium, which is not enough elements to form rocky planets).

When I was real small kid, i used to imagine that life needed one main thing (besides a liquid), energy. I didn’t matter where the energy came from. Before the whole hydrothermal vent thing happened, I always wondered if life found a way like in Jurassic Park. What if a planet with no sun had life. If the sun went away, maybe small critters could survive the extinction event. All the energy they could need would be found around volcanoes or other geothermal activity like hot springs. Liquids could be found by this heat and also life. I never thought hydrothermal vents existed but that really only helped my idea. New primary producers could evolve that use thermal energy rather than solar energy. At the time though, my science teacher told me that wasn’t possible. Life always needed a stars light.

"They're exposed to the freezing cold of outer space." You know it's a nearly ubiquitous misconception that space is cold, you should be taking every opportunity to at least not reinforce that idea.

And stability is probably not a good thing for the life under those sheets of ice (from the discoverer's perspective). As I understand it, changes in selection pressures are the most important thing for evolution. So if there is life around those thermal vents, and the environment is almost completely static and stable, then I wouldn't be surprised if complex multicellular life never evolves, even over much longer spans of time than it took on Earth. I would expect life to stay more or less at its most primitive

Rouge moons could have their cores heated up this way, and it could be sustained for potentially tens of billions of years, or even hundreds of billions to trillions if orbiting a failed sub brown dwarf, but also a super Jupiter (as they are the same.) so these moons could sustain heat in their cores long enough so that another moon, Astroid, or even another rouge planet joined the party. This could gravitationally change the orbits of the planet and moon we started with, and thus heat up the core of the rouge moon again once it’s cooled. The earth alone will take 91 billion more years for its core to solidify, and in addition to the 4.6 billion years it’s already existed, that’s 95.6 billion years for an earth sized planet. And for a rouge planet that is on the verge of being a mini Neptune, it be 10 earthly masses. It would also have that atmosphere mentioned in the video with hydrogen, making it habitable (theoretically) on the surface. 10 earth masses is 10 times the gravity, which is roughly 10 times the gravitational force, which heats up the core 10 times as much. This should mean about 10 times as much time until the core solidifies, which makes an incredible 956 billion years on the upper end from start to finish! And a large moon of this planet would have at least a few trillion years under the surface. I don't believe that it is logical to apply anthropocentric constraints on the evolution of such an alien "civilization", they may very well be able to manipulate their environment in different ways and even develop more advanced technologies, tho none would be recognizable to us earthlings.

What if, in a way, we are identical to that "intelligent alient" in that rougue planet? I mean, the same way they are trapped under the ice, we might be trapped in this 90-million-light-year-or-so "universe horizon". In a way they cannot store star energy, we might also cannot store some kind of energy from "outside" our universe. In a way they don't know the existence of star and star energy, we might not know some form of energy from outside our universe. And the same way they don't have woods, coal, or oil, we might also do not have one or some equal materials that will allow us, for example, travel faster than light. In a way they never invent fire, we might never invent something so critical that allow us to journey beyond our universe... We always think that to be able to travel faster than light, we need to bend space and time, maybe by wormhole or something. But, in a way our alien buddy never have any concept of fire (they might never even have any thought about the fire at all), we might also never have concept, or even never have any thought at all about something so elegant yet so critical to move our civilization beyond our universe. Or a concept or method or material more elegant than just bending space-time or making a wormhole... We may never be able to find or solve Theory of Everything because we are lack of material or concept so critical to find and solve the theory... And so on, and so on... In a way, we are identical with our little alien buddy under the ice of a rougue planet :-(

Wouldn't an intelligent lifeform in such a scenario figure out that the ice above them can't be infinite by the phenomenon of pressure? Pressure is very apparent when being under water, any lifeform there (intelligent or not) perceives it when changing altitude, though intuitively as a relative rather than absolute quantity, much like heat/temperature. At this early point, they might think of positive and negative pressure as symmetric and potentially infinite.
But if they're intelligent in a way similar to humans and challenge traditional beliefs, or maybe by accident, they would eventually discover vacuum, i.e. observe that negative pressure can not be increased beyond a certain point.
This way they should realize that there is no negative pressure that increases with altitude above their comfortable altitude indefinitely, but rather that there must be some altitude where pressure is (close to) absolute zero (i.e. not further reducible), and that there can be (almost) no more mass above that altitude.
They could even go further and estimate the height of the ice sheet under the assumption that it's homogeneous, by measuring the pressure difference induced by a given change in altitude of some unit distance, dividing the pressure against vacuum at their current altitude by that difference, and scaling with the density ratio of ice and water derived from measuring the buoyancy of ice pulled under water. If they noticed in their altitude-pressure-difference measurements that it very slightly changes with altitude (gravitational pull is weaker the further away from the center of mass you get), and have discovered calculus, they can refine their estimation by adjusting for that factor.
Imagine how super hyped up such a civilization must get from this scientific discovery, and the sheer wonder and admiration when an expedition in pressurized suits and water in them makes it to the top of the ice sheet and they see the night sky for the first time, ever.

Therefore, I think it is a good possibility that there might be more advanced or less advanced lifeforms compared to us living under ice on Rogue Planets or alikes. I think this because, when we seek traces of life in space, we tend to look for near-star planets, and finding one like our Earth is hard because liquid water is not there. Many people think that aliens could look like anything we can imagine. But there are many limits in our universe.

Can someone help me write as many criteria as possible for life to form?

I'll name a few things I know:

1. Only a few atoms on the periodic table are able to form weird complex structures that could later become life. One is carbon, another is maybe silica (can't remember). Carbon is very abundant, silica isn't. If there's life out there, the highest chances are that it's carbon based, then silica.

2. It has to form on a body in space: a planet, star, moon or an asteroid. It cannot form in open space, or at least, let's say the chances are ridiculously small. So, every lifeform out there is enslaved and shaped by gravity.

3. It has to be a material system. A machine that consumes energy and spends it. It has to reproduce and multiply, or have another way of evolving. But if it's just one being, chances are low that it will survive. Chances are very low that it's just one. Every lifeform out there probably is many.

4. Local energy source. No need for explanation.

5. Heat.
There has to be a local source of heat or the lifeform has to produce heat from energy. The lifeform has to need heat. No heat means no life. Because on the absolute 0, only the atoms move. And the cold=nothing. Warmth is movement. Warmth is life.

6. Stable enough environment. To not kill all life in there.

7. Turbulent enough environment. For a sharp natural selection. Nothing great ever came out of perfect peace and stability. Slow evolution is a great risk for survival.

How could complex life, let alone intelligent life, arise on a planet without sunlight? No sunlight, no photosynthesis. No photosynthesis, no oxygen. No oxygen, no aerobic respiration. The only form of energy that life on such a planet has available is chemosynthesis, which is terribly inefficient when compared to aerobic respiration. Complex life needs a LOT of energy to support its complexity, and aerobic respiration is pretty much the only source that provides that much energy. The only way that complex, intelligent life could exist on a rogue planet is if the planet initially had a stable orbit around a star for a long enough time for photosynthetic life (e.g. algae) to produce enough oxygen to saturate the oceans, and then had its orbit destabilized by a more massive planet or star passing too close.

You left out the part where we shouldn't have a molten core anymore. The only reason we do (as far as we can reconstruct) is the same reason we have such a large moon and such a strong magnetic field: Billions of years ago, a Mars-sized planet hit us at a low angle, sheared off enough mass to form the moon, and then sunk into our core, adding both iron and a massive amount of heat. Heck, even Venus is geologically inert at this point. The odds of that happening anywhere else in the universe aren't necessarily impossible, but it would have to be incredibly rare.

And then there's me sitting in my room watching these videos.

An intelligent enough species on such a planet would learn what "air" is, possibly in the way we discovered vacuum pressure. Gas accumulates, bubbles up, and no doubt would get trapped in a large amount somewhere on this theoretica planet.

If they could create chambers with out water, they would learn about "dry" and the benefits of working with "dryness", much the way we are doing experiments in space with zero G.
Furthermore, they would use less effort and energy, since it's far easier to explore "dryness" or "air" underwater than for us to explore space.

They could become quite technologically advanced. It's bizarre to think it, because we are "dry people" and we'd need to think and understand like a species evolved over hundreds of thousands of years to become "wet people".

I think that a species like this can reach a point of intelligence where they escape to the surface, but it would be incredibly difficult and thus, it would take a lot of time. Their technology would revolve around harvesting energy from both fossil fuels and the core of the planet since they don't have sunlight. They would have to develop technology to dig so that they can get more energy from the core of the planet. This could be used by them to also dig through the ice above them and eventually reach the surface.

The biggest hurdle they face is evolving into an amphibious species that deep under the surface of the planet. They would have to be amphibious in order to conduct experiments for technology. To do this, there would need to be a cave under the surface of the planet and a species of animal that live close to the cave for generations. Evolution would then have to develop a way to live in the cave and in the water, but they would primarily live underwater. That's just scratching the surface of evolutionary hurdles needed to escape to the surface.

Some intelligent civilizations might indeed be born, mature and die off not knowing there's more to their existence than they thought. People were the same until psychedelics were discovered. Now they act as a catalyst for change. A key to the cosmic void of possibilities. They give the proper user access to dimensions and emotions vastly superior and higher than that of the ones living in wishful ignorance. The first few sentences of H. P. Lovecraft's infamous "The Call of Cthulhu" go as follows:

"The most merciful thing in the world, I think, is the inability of the human mind to correlate all its contents. We live on a placid island of ignorance in the midst of black seas of infinity, and it was not meant that we should voyage far. The sciences, each straining in its own direction, have hitherto harmed us little; but some day the piecing together of dissociated knowledge will open up such terrifying vistas of reality, and of our frightful position therein, that we shall either go mad from the revelation or flee from the deadly light into the peace and safety of a new dark age."

Just take a moment and think about that.

The problem with a rogue planet that has a thick hydrogen atmosphere, is that the hydrogen atmosphere combusts rather easily in the presence of oxygen. Complex life on earth is possible in part thanks to the presence of oxygen to enable our cells' aerobic respiration, which provides much more energy than fermentation or anaerobic metabolism of compounds such as methane. Therefore complex life on hydrogen insulated rogue planets either eats up its protective mantle due to the release of oxygen, or has to deal with way smaller energy budgets. Oh, and of course the surface atmospheric pressure would be enormous, too.

Not quite true! Life forms don't strictly need liquid water to survive. Liquid methane is also a valid substance for the formation of life!
In fact, most scientists agree that the key ingredients for life to form are as follows: heat, an environment where mixing can occur (ocean currents for example), the major elemental building blocks (carbon, nitrogen, oxygen, phosphorous, sulfur and hydrogen) and light/radiation. The last one may be up for debate, when you consider the life forms that populate the Mariana Trench, several kilometers below our own ocean's surface.

It's not just frozen oceans that can trap species on a planet; if life formed on planets with significantly higher gravity than Earth, the rocket equation would require more fuel to carry payloads to escape velocity than is feasible to pack into a spacecraft. I think it is not impossible, that such life forms can't invent ways to use metal for materials. Vulcanic activity is also possible under water and any form of life, no matter of what it is made, has a benifit of "warmer" environments. Warmer is of cause relative, but chemistry works faster there and when you move from 10 K to 20 K the kinetic energy for the molecules is doubled! As long as life building machines like our proteins are not broken up by these relativly high speeds life in this regions will be faster than life elsewhere. Therefore intelligent life might prefer such places as we prefered to live next to warm places and used for this need fire places. Of course you can't ignite everywhere a black smoker, but you still can use them. And there you can possible watch new chemistry happen and maybe one these new discovered processes is melting metal into new forms. Yes, you also wont go even close to a vulcano, but the possibility still exists, that some living being can manage to get close enough to make use of it.
And you do not need wood to invent tools. Many human tribes used only stones and bones and the evolution of bones is in my opinion a very logical step, when creatures become to big to carry their mass without. So even without the discovery of fire, tools will exist and tools can be used to do further exploration (maybe even trough that mysterious ice sheet...)

The phrase "Up to half of all planets born could end up as rogues" in the context of the video implies, IMHO, that from these rogue planets a significant number is Earth-sized (edit: Earth-mass).
However, one of the sources you provide for it (The demographics of rocky free-floating planets and their detectability by WFIRST, 2017) explicitly states that "few Earth-mass free-floating planets are ejected during the planet formation process". Figure 5 of the article actually shows that in the simulation where Earth-sized (edit: Earth-mass) planets have been ejected, they make up ~0.1% (or even less) of all rogue planets.
That's not the kind of planets the video is about and I'm afraid that, essentially, your wording of the phrase actually deludes viewer.

The Rogue planet scenario I've always been fascinated by is a bit different. Intelligent life evolves on a planet,  a technological society emerges, and then the planet becomes a Rogue. Could they survive? Could we? It's not too far fetched. Sure, if that society had space capabilities, many would escape that way. But how many would be left behind? Think about our current state: We are a space faring civilization, but up to a point, we haven't yet developed the technology necessary to survive in space for extended periods of time without being dependent on the earth. But we already have technology that would allow us to survive in a rogue planet on the surface. Think, for example, nuclear submarines. If the earth were to suddenly become a Rogue planet, you could theoretically survive inside a nuclear sub, even as the ocean and atmosphere around you freezes. A nuclear sub has its own powerplant fit to last a few decades, it creates its own heat, its own air, it recycles water. The only thing it doesn't produce is food, but we already know how to do that, if the power is available. Could a technological society such as ourselves create nuclear-sub like refugees, with enough nuclear fuel to last a reduced number of people for generations and generations?

It's worth noting that a big part of why the earth's innards are still so hot is because of nuclear decay. The larger a planet, the more fissile material available and the longer you can have differentiated solid inner core to act as a dynamo, etc. For example, because Mars is so small, its innards have cooled to the point that there is no longer any real dynamo effect to produce a massive protective magnetosphere like the Earth's. Being warm on the inside is a huge piece of what makes life on the Earth possible.

1:13 Food Chain

Personally, I don't think life on rogue worlds could make it past the microbial stage.  If you look at the life around hydrothermal vents on Earth, all the animals evolved from ancestors who lived in shallow water at some point.  This is because complex life requires high energy resources to start with, which means they need large amounts of oxygen, which requires metabolic activity so abundant that organisms resort to using water as a reducer, which requires a much greater energy source than the vents can provide.  There could be an exception for planets where life developed in the presence of a star before the planet was kicked out of the system, but even then, the oxygen would be depleted over time and complex life would ultimately go extinct.

No mention of radioactivity?  About half the heat that escapes from Earth is replaced by natural radioactive decay.  It's also interesting that larger planets would have enough insulation to remain warm enough to sustain life for many billions of years.  Jupiter gives off twice as much heat as it gets from the sun even after 4+ billion years, for instance.  It will be neat to see what computer models predict for internal temperatures and liquid water availability for rogue gas giants over billions of years.

The only missing remark is, a second genesis has never been discovered, here on Earth. So the whole premise that life is a common thing, goes against the evidence, that life happened only once, during the roughly 4 billion years the Earth has been hospitable to life. The whole optimism that life is common, even inevitable, seems to completely go against every evidence we have.
Also, tidal forces caused by orbiting moons, provide so little energy differential, it's unlikely it could perform any work, like power up life. We already have to resort to extreme environmental conditions (lightning, high pressure, etc) to "spontaneously" synthesize the building blocks of life, in a lab. And it's unlikely that the precursors to life were any more energy-efficient than the evolved life we have now. So the whole idea of an ocean being warmed uniformly through tidal forces, being able to kickstart life, is a big leap, from a lot of baseless assumptions.

This theory on rogue planet life being essentially trapped under the ice, ignorant of the outside universe could be a potential answer to the fermi paradox. Its estimated that 90% of all planets in the universe are rogue planets and that there are many, many more rogue stars outside of our galaxy than within it.

Using these rogue bodies, we could potentially island hop our way to new galaxies. Cuz, let's face it! Even travelling at relativistic speeds, it would still take hundreds of thousands, if not millions of years to reach a new galaxy. And doing it in one shot with an insanely large ship would be impractical.

Unless we somehow invent faster-than-light travel technology or wormholes, the idea of colonizing galaxies using rogue planets as staging points or convenient resources is about as remote and alien as the life we may find on these rogue planets.

5:37 "The most likely forms of life are bacteria and other micro organisms." For a channel that prides itself on science, this has got to be the dumbest statement they've made yet. A single cell as we know it consists of a vast complexity of machines and information with a probability of 10 to the power of 80 coming into existence out of pure randomness, which dwarfs the total number of atoms in the universe. Life did not evolve in earth. It was 100% designed. The past 10 years of discoveries in molecular biology effectively killed off Darwinian evolution. You would have to be an absolute idiot to continue to believe in Darwinian evolution given what we now know at the molecular level. So please stop spreading this pathetic myth. The only thing it's good for is bedtime stories.

As for the Drake equation that estimated the possibility of life on other planets, that is so out-dated that in this past year scientists published a more up-to-date article that indicates that there is a 40% chance of us being alone in the universe.

As a starting point, you should do a video on the virtually impossible scenario that DNA could randomly come into existence. And you think that DNA would randomly form to create life elsewhere in the universe?? lol

This channel really isn't about science. It's fictional infotainment.

6:07 hmm, I would actually disagree with this point made. I think aquatic aliens could be able to produce metals by use of galvanic cells, long story short, you take two vessels containing concentrations of different metals dissolved in water, stick in electrodes (with could just be minerals containing high proportions of each) and you'll get pure metal on one of the electrodes. With the case of forging, while iron would be largely inaccessible metals like aluminium and lead can be shaped easily and could be produced galvanically.
I'd imagine iron being treated as an unworkable waste product seeing that that they couldn't just be melted underwater.

You could use precious metals like gold, which is already pure in natural environments to use wiring for these electrodes and you could use hydrothermal vents as an energy source. It'd be difficult and progress could be slow, but I do think post-singularity civilisations could develop on rogue planets
That settles it then! We need to go to Europa and see if there's any life down there in it's oceans.
